In terms of probabilities, this could mean that each offspring has a 75% chance of having at least one dominant allele (black), and a 25% chance of having none (all recessives, white). So, if we're looking at dihybrid crosses or other combinations, how do the parents' genotypes look? The options given are A to J, but let me list them: A. Bb × Bb  
B. BB × BB and Bb × bb

D. bb × bb  
E. bb × BB

If a parent were homozygous recessive (bb), then every offspring would inherit a b from both parents, resulting in bb and hence white coats.
